unit: Unit 8 | Inference for Categorical Data: Chi-Square
title: Contribute to Test Statistic
question_text:
Suppose Kathy bought a large bag of candy that comes in four flavors: cherry, strawberry, orange, and lemon.
Out of the $84\text{ pieces of candy}$, $23$ were cherry, $24$ were strawberry, $21$ were orange, and $16$ were lemon. Kathy performed a chi-squared goodness of fit test to determine if the candy flavors were evenly distributed.
What flavor contributed the most to the chi-squared test statistic?
solution:
First, find the expected counts. If they were evenly distributed, each flavor would occur $25\%$ of the time since there are four distinct flavors.

One would expect $84\cdot 0.25 = 21\text{ candies}$ of each flavor in every bag.

Find each component of the test statistic to see that lemon contributes the most.

Cherry: $\dfrac{(23-21)^2}{21} = 0.19$

Strawberry: $\dfrac{(24-21)^2}{21} = 0.43 $

Orange: $\dfrac{(21-21)^2}{21} = 0$

Lemon: $\dfrac{(16-21)^2}{21} = 1.19$

Thus, the correct answer is Choice 'D'.
